Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Charlie was diagnosed in 2016 with Prostate cancer and was sadly already at stage 4, during this time he had chemotherapy then had to battle many complications one including a blocked valve which led on to open heart surgery, he was proud to be a member of the zip club, he came back fighting, amazingly Charlie battled on and we were able to make more happy memories before the cancer spread to his spine in January 2020 where he attempted radiotherapy to give us more time but unfortunately in February 2020 when returning home he became immobilised , that’s when Sarah Reed from Macmillan started supporting both him and the family until he lost his fight on Wednesday 14th October 2020.  We were thankful he was at home with his family which was his last wish.

story: My incredible Nan was diagnosed with terminal cancer. A type called Lymphoma. She attended one of the most incredible places ever. My Nan was so poorly, and needed to undergo a stem cell transplant in order to save her life. Each treatment costs between £50,000-£12,000. She stayed in the cotton rooms, a hotel which accommodates for patients of the UCHL. By no means does it look like a hospital, but just a normal hotel room. They took care of my Nan and granddad so well, and met all her needs. The nurses, doctors, specialists and all other staff at the Macmillan centre and cotton rooms, worked so so so hard; day in and day out. My Nan is my best friend and my inspiration, and it’s my turn to make a difference. I want to make my Nan proud, and help save lives of many other poorly people with amazingly sad stories, who deserve longer in this world. I never ever heard my Nan moan once, never sulked, never took a day for granted. We are so lucky. This is my chance to help out. I’m not a marathon runner, what so ever, but I’m going to give 100%. Please donate, even if it’s £1 it DOES make a difference. Thank you.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On Friday 30th October 2020 the Amey Scottish Regional Hub will be hosting a virtual Halloween Spooktacular Party on Microsoft Teams, in aid of Cancer Research UK.

It will take place between 6.30pm and 7.30pm. There will be competitions and prizes, and all staff and their families are welcome to join us, either as contestants or viewers. A Teams Meeting invite will be circulated prior to the event, and you must pre-register as a contestant by Wednesday 28th October.

The running order will be:

6.30pm - Welcome
6.40pm - Costume competition (adults) - Prizes for 1st & 2nd Best Costume
6.50pm - Costume competition (children) - Prizes for 1st & 2nd Best Costume
7.00pm - Apple Bobbing (adults) - Prizes for most apples retrieved in 60 seconds*
7.10pm - Apple Bobbing (children) - Prizes for most apples retrieved in 60 seconds*
7.20pm - Best Halloween household - Prizes for 1st & 2nd Best Decorated home
7.30pm - Party ends

All participants must take part on camera. Supporters/viewers do not need to be on camera, and can use Microsoft Teams chat or audio to lend their support.

APPLE BOBBING*

 - Each contestant must start with either 8 apples (for adults) and 6 apples (for children). Ensure you have enough apples for each participant in your household.
 - For the purposes of this competition children are those aged between 8 and 15 years of age.
 - Fill a clean basin, bucket, cooler or bin with cool, but not freezing, water and place it on stable surface.
 - Please ensure the container you choose will comfortably fit the number of apples, allowing some movement and ensuring that there is an index finger’s depth between the apples and the bottom of the container.
 - It’s worth putting some towels down and being prepared to get soaked!
 - Winner is whoever retrieves the most apples in the shortest time.

story:
Kathy was my big sister. Despite our age difference, she was a consistent and loving presence in my life. Most of my fondest childhood memories, and many of my adult ones, feature Kathy. Her kindness to me, especially at times when everything else felt a bit uncertain, her willingness to laugh, and her love for her family are examples to us all. This love grew to encompass Coree (who she, from a sense of compassion, and perhaps sisterly-nosiness, invited to join us for a Christmas Eve celebration very early on in our relationship. Luckily Coree received the seal of approval) and later Teddy. Our last visit included a trip to the outdoor centre near Kathy’s home. Teddy was enamoured with the ride-on construction vehicles and Kathy joined him in his fun. When Coree and I tried to chivvy him along to see the other exhibits, she turned to us and said ‘He’s having so much fun, let him play!’ She was determined, despite treatments which often left her poorly, to squeeze every last bit of pleasure out of life and encouraged us to do the same.


Mourning her passing, and celebrating her life, was made more difficult due to the pandemic and I’ve struggled since to figure out how best to commemorate her life. I’m going to be 40 on 9 November and ask you to join me in chipping in a few pounds for Cancer Research UK and raise a glass, chip in a few pounds and raise a glass to my beloved sister.

eventName: Growing a moustache for Marie Curie
story:
Hi everyone, I've decided to do my own version of Movember* this year in memory of my dad Peter and my granny Jean - my mum's mum.

Granny died at the age of 91 in January 2010 after a short illness, while Dad in August of that year at the age of 56. He had been diagnosed with kidney cancer 11 months earlier. Dad and Granny are both fondly remembered and very much missed.

I'll be shaving off my beard and moustache on October 31st and spending the month of November growing a magnificent** moustache.

Dad sported a 'tache in his younger days though he was more of a goatee man later in life, so I'm pretty sure he'd approve.

I'll be raising money for a charity that means a lot to us as a family – Marie Curie, who provide care for people with terminal illnesses. Granny was a Marie Curie nurse, and when Dad was ill at home in his final weeks, they were a great support for him and Mum.

I'll be charting my progress with daily updates on Instagram and Facebook, so feel free to come and laugh at my lip fuzz there.

Thanks in advance for your support - every little bit helps.

Chris

*This isn't an official Movember fundraiser but if you would like to support the Movember Foundation and their work for men's health, visit movember.com

**Magnificence not guaranteed

story:
Over the past year, dying has become a front-of-mind issue for us all. The pandemic and our ageing population means its never been more pressing to make sure we have the right care and support in place to be able to protect and cherish each other as we reach the final months, weeks, days and hours of our lives.

Every day and night, our Marie Curie nurses and frontline staff,
continue providing vital support to dying people and their families in their own homes and at our Cardiff and Vale Hospice. 

There has never been more need for Marie Curie. Caring for people
in their own homes or at our hospice relieves the pressure off our hospitals when beds are needed more than ever.                                  

But all of this will take money. We rely heavily on the generosity of the public to help deliver our care, but as events and activities are postponed or cancelled, we face a devastating loss to our income. 

Whilst our frontline teams are working day and night to meet growing need, Marie Curie needs to raise £13,888 every hour, 24 hours a day.

The impact of the coronavirus will be felt for a long time, particularly among families grieving the loss of a loved one.  We have updated
information and support on our website if a family member or friend is living with terminal illness, or if you have a terminal illness yourself, you may be worried about coronavirus. www.mariecurie.org.uk or please call our support line.

We’re here for you on 0800 090 2309

We know there is not a person or family in the country who is not touched by this emergency. But dying people and their families need all our help now.  We cannot thank you enough for your ongoing support, and for standing by our side at this time.
